words.definition: A set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten the development lifecycle and deliver high-quality software continuously.
words.example: DevOps automates code integration, testing, and deployment.
examples: DevOps bridges the gap between developers and operations teams.
words.notes: DevOps culture emphasizes collaboration and automation.

words.definition: Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery/Deployment, a set of practices and tools for automating software build, test, and deployment processes.
words.example: CI/CD pipelines run tests and deploy code automatically.
examples: CI/CD reduces manual errors and speeds up releases.

words.definition: An automated sequence of processes that build, test, and deploy software, often triggered by code changes.
words.example: A pipeline runs unit tests before deploying to production.
examples: Pipelines ensure consistent, repeatable deployments.
words.notes: Common in GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins.

words.definition: The use of tools and scripts to perform tasks without human intervention, improving efficiency and reliability.
words.example: Automation handles code builds and deployments.
examples: Automation reduces errors and speeds up workflows.
words.notes: Automation is central to DevOps and CI/CD.

words.definition: The process of compiling source code into executable software or deployable artifacts.
words.example: The build step compiles code and bundles assets.
examples: Builds are triggered automatically in CI pipelines.
words.notes: Build artifacts are tested and deployed.

words.definition: To release and install software to a production or staging environment where users can access it.
words.example: Code is deployed to production after passing tests.
examples: Deployments can be automated or manual.
words.notes: Deployments are tracked for rollback if needed.

words.definition: A version of software that is made available to users after passing all build and test phases.
words.example: The latest release includes new features and bug fixes.
examples: Releases are tagged and documented.
words.notes: Release management is part of CI/CD.

words.definition: To revert software or infrastructure to a previous stable state after a failed deployment or release.
words.example: Rollback is triggered if the deployment fails.
examples: Rollbacks prevent extended downtime.

words.definition: A system that records changes to files over time, enabling collaboration, history tracking, and code management.
words.example: Git is the most popular version control system.
examples: Version control enables branching and merging.

words.definition: A storage location for code, configuration, or artifacts, typically managed by a version control system.
words.example: The repository contains all project source code.
examples: Repositories can be public or private.

words.definition: A parallel version of code in a repository, used for developing features, fixing bugs, or experimenting safely.
words.example: Developers create branches for new features.
examples: Branches are merged after review and testing.

words.definition: To combine changes from different branches in a repository into a single branch.
words.example: Merging integrates feature code into main.
examples: Merge conflicts must be resolved manually.
words.notes: Pull requests initiate merges in GitHub.

words.definition: A request to merge code changes from one branch to another, usually reviewed by team members before approval.
words.example: Submit a pull request for code review.
examples: Pull requests enable collaborative development.

words.definition: The process of examining code changes for quality, correctness, and style before merging into the main branch.
words.example: Code review catches bugs before deployment.
examples: Automated tools assist with code review.

words.definition: The use of scripts and tools to automatically execute software tests, improving speed and reliability.
words.example: Test automation runs unit and integration tests in CI.
examples: Automated tests catch bugs early in the pipeline.
words.notes: Test automation is key to continuous delivery.

words.definition: A file or set of files produced during the build process, such as binaries, packages, or documentation.
words.example: Build artifacts are stored for deployment.
examples: Artifacts are versioned and archived.
words.notes: Artifacts are used in multiple pipeline stages.

words.definition: A lightweight, standalone, executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, such as code, runtime, and libraries.
words.example: Docker containers simplify deployment across environments.
examples: Containers isolate apps for consistency and security.

words.definition: A popular platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers.
words.example: Docker packages code and dependencies for deployment.
examples: Docker images are the blueprints for containers.

words.definition: The automated configuration, coordination, and management of computer systems, applications, and services.
words.example: Kubernetes provides orchestration for containerized applications.
examples: Orchestration automates scaling and failover.

words.definition: An open-source platform for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
words.example: Kubernetes orchestrates Docker containers across clusters.
examples: Kubernetes supports rolling updates and self-healing.
words.notes: Kubernetes is the industry standard for orchestration.

words.definition: The practice of managing and provisioning computing infrastructure using machine-readable configuration files, rather than manual processes.
words.example: Terraform enables infrastructure as code for cloud resources.
examples: IaC improves repeatability and reduces errors.

words.definition: An open-source IaC tool for defining and provisioning infrastructure using declarative configuration files.
words.example: Terraform automates cloud infrastructure setup.
examples: Terraform supports AWS, Azure, GCP, and more.
words.notes: Terraform is widely used for cloud automation.

words.definition: An open-source automation tool for configuration management, application deployment, and task automation.
words.example: Ansible automates server setup and updates.
examples: Ansible uses YAML for playbooks.
words.notes: Ansible is agentless and easy to use.

words.definition: An open-source automation server for building, testing, and deploying software, widely used in CI/CD pipelines.
words.example: Jenkins automates builds and test execution.
examples: Jenkins integrates with hundreds of plugins.
words.notes: Jenkins is free and open source.

words.definition: A commercial CI/CD server from Atlassian for automated builds, tests, and deployments, tightly integrated with Jira and Bitbucket.
words.example: Bamboo automates software delivery pipelines.
examples: Bamboo offers out-of-the-box Atlassian integration.

words.definition: A popular open-source suite for automated testing of web applications across browsers and platforms.
words.example: Selenium automates browser-based regression testing.
examples: Selenium supports multiple programming languages.

words.definition: The process of planning, organizing, and controlling the testing process, often with specialized tools.
words.example: Test management tools track test cases and results.
examples: Zephyr and Azure Test Plans are popular solutions.

words.definition: Testing to ensure that new code changes do not break existing functionality.
words.example: Automated regression testing runs after every build.
examples: Regression tests catch unintended side effects.

words.definition: Testing individual units or components of code to ensure they function as intended.
words.example: Unit testing validates functions and modules in isolation.
examples: Mocha and Jest are popular unit testing frameworks.
words.notes: Forms the base of the test automation pyramid.

words.definition: Testing the interaction between integrated units or components to ensure they work together correctly.
words.example: Integration testing verifies APIs and data flows.
examples: Integration tests catch issues between modules.

words.definition: Testing software features against functional requirements to ensure correct behavior.
words.example: Functional testing checks if user stories are met.
examples: Automated functional tests validate business logic.

words.definition: Testing to determine how a system performs under load, including speed, scalability, and stability.
words.example: Performance testing identifies bottlenecks before release.
examples: Tools: JMeter, Gatling, Locust.

words.definition: Testing to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses in software, infrastructure, and processes.
words.example: Security testing checks for XSS and SQL injection.
examples: Automated tools scan for known vulnerabilities.
words.notes: Essential for compliance and risk management.

words.definition: The process where end users validate that software meets their needs and requirements before release.
words.example: User acceptance testing ensures usability and satisfaction.
examples: UAT is the final step before production.

words.definition: A preliminary test to check the basic functionality of an application after a build or deployment.
words.example: Smoke testing verifies critical features after updates.
examples: Smoke tests catch major issues early.

words.definition: The ongoing process of tracking application and infrastructure health, performance, and security in real time.
words.example: Continuous monitoring detects issues before users are affected.
examples: Tools: Prometheus, Grafana, Datadog.
words.notes: Ensures reliability and rapid incident response.
